metadata.title: FAQ
metadata.description: Common questions about Y-Link, the AI DMX controller, the pilot program, and email preferences.

hero.label: Support
hero.title: Frequently Asked Questions
hero.body: Get clarity on what's automated, how operators maintain control, and how to sign up or unsubscribe.

items.a: The controller analyzes audio for tempo, phrases, and energy. It builds cues, transitions, and guardrails that follow the track without manual programming.

items.q: Can operators still control the rig?
items.a: Yes. Operators can approve looks, lock intensity, rehearse sections, and override automation. The goal is predictable playback with human control.
Each step is budgeted, and playback is validated before output. Runtime is tuned for low jitter in clubs and small venues.

items.q: Which fixtures and universes are supported?
items.a: We target common DMX universes with profiles for clubs and small venues. Universe planning and saturation checks run before playback.

items.q: How do I join the pilot or pre-order?
items.a: Use the form on the homepage or pilot page. The pilot is time-limited (approx. 4-8 weeks), with Y1 hardware loaned and returned afterward. We take in a small, curated group to test stability, timing, and UX.

items.q: How do I unsubscribe from emails?
items.a: Each email has an unsubscribe link. You can also visit /unsubscribe?token=<your-token> to remove your address immediately.

metadata.title: DMX Basics
metadata.description: Understand DMX signals, universes, and fixtures as a foundation for AI-driven light.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Basics
hero.body: A brief introduction to DMX so your fixture planning aligns with AI-generated cues from the Y-Link controller.

signal.title: Signal and Universe
signal.body: DMX512 sends 512 channel values per universe. Each fixture uses channels based on the selected mode. Predictable automation requires clear mapping of fixtures to universes and overview of channel usage.
items: Map all fixtures with address and channel footprint.
Keep universes under safe utilization to avoid timing issues.
Document cabling, splitters, and nodes.

modes.title: Fixture Modes
modes.body: Choose modes that balance control against channel count. Higher modes give more control but use more channels. The AI planner needs correct patch to avoid saturation.

metadata.title: Fixture Addressing
metadata.description: Learn to address fixtures correctly for stable AI-driven light sequences.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: Fixture Addressing
hero.body: Correct addressing ensures AI-planned cues hit the right channel every time.

plan.title: Plan Your Patch
items: Keep an updated patch list with start address and mode.
Group similar fixtures for tidy universes.
Avoid overlap by reserving buffer zones where rigs change often.

validate.title: Validate Against Controller
validate.body: Y-Link checks the patch before show. Mismatches between patch and actual rig can cause wrong mapping and timing drift.

metadata.title: DMX Universes and Scaling
metadata.description: How to plan universes and scale the rig without losing timing.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Universes and Scaling
hero.body: Good universe planning ensures AI-generated signals maintain timing even as the rig grows.

distribute.title: Distribute the Load
items: Keep universes under safe utilization; avoid pushing to 512 on busy shows.
Distribute power consumption and cable routes to minimize noise and loss.
Plan reserved universes for temporary fixtures.

scaling.title: Scaling
scaling.body: When adding universes, ensure the controller and nodes support synchronous clock and latency monitoring. Y-Link enforces timing per universe, but needs correct topology.

metadata.title: Latency and Jitter in DMX
metadata.description: How to measure and control latency and jitter in an AI-controlled DMX rig.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: Latency and Jitter in DMX
hero.body: Timing is the core value in music-reactive lighting. Here's how we measure, budget, and monitor latency and jitter.

measurement.title: Measurement
items: Measure end-to-end latency with known test audio and sensor on light.
Look for jitter (variation) between cues and output.
Log under full load, not just in an empty room.

control.title: Control
control.body: Y-Link budgets each step and monitors drift. If deviations are detected, output is tightened or the operator is notified. Keep network and nodes stable for best results.

hero.title: DMX Best Practices

items: Verify patch and universes against the rig.

Define operator override and emergency procedures.

during.title: During Show

Log deviations for later adjustment.

metadata.title: DMX Troubleshooting

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: DMX Troubleshooting
hero.body: Typical problems and quick actions to keep the show stable.

errors.title: Common Errors
items: Signal drops: check cables, termination, and nodes.
Wrong mapping: verify patch and addressing.
Timing glitches: look for network load and node health.

checklist.title: Quick Checklist
items: Confirm universe and address assignment.
Check that guardrails and safety limits are active.
Restart nodes on fault condition, log the event.
